sp.p: Oh miſs, I do congratulate myſelf on de felicity of meeting you dus at home.—If I can carry her away, I ſhall be even vid her father for calling me a tailleur.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: But law, colonel, how ſhocking you're dreſſed!

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Do you think ſo? Mr. Lackland ſaid 'twas ver pretty my dear.—Oh! you be von lovely girl! how I do love you! Pray, miſs, was you ever in love?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Oh yes.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Have a you?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Only nine times. Let me ſee. Three times before I was out of my ſlips; twice while I was at Hackney boarding-ſchool; once with my guitar maſter; then with Frank Frippery; then with Dicky Pettitoes. No, only eight; for I don't reckon the handſome ſtay-maker of Duck-lane.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Then be in love with me the ninth time; and ſcamper off with me.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Scamper with you! Why dont you aſk father's conſent.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: No, it ſound a ſo mean.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Why, as you ſay, it does ſound a little of Bow Bell. Well; and then it w •• l make a pure noiſe in the papers—the elopement—the purſuit— the marriage—the making up—Beſides, I'm in love with your vis a vis. So come along; I'll ſcamper off with you.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Vel ſaid, my little angel, come along.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: But hold—Will you excuſe me to Sir Shenkin ap Griffin?

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Excuſe you to Sir Shenkin! for what?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Becauſe I promiſed to run away with him; and I came here to meet him.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Indeed! but you know I came a de firſt.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Why that's true. And firſt come firſt ſerved, as father ſays to his cuſtomers in the ſhop at home—Come along.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Hold, my dear, I muſt juſt ſtep—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Why I thought you was going to ſcamper off with me.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: I ſhall ſoon be back—but as I don't know what may happen, I vill juſt order my man to put up de powder, de pomatum, and de dancing pump

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Well then, do make haſte, colonel.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: I have prought the prieſt. He looks as merry as a pard and as ſmart as a truid.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: But why did you ſtay ſo long? I have been crying my eyes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: Ton't cry, my tear. Wipe a your eye, ton't weep.—My dear, the chaiſe is ready for us, and a ſulky for father Domine.

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: But muſt I deſert the colonel for you?

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: To be ſure you muſt. But I will put on a pair of jack boots, and trive you myſelf, for the poys here are as ſluggiſh as their horſes. They ſmack their whips, and they cry gee whu! but they are as ſlow as ſnails, though they gabble like turkey cocks.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Well, but come now, don't let us wait for the boots.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: I'll be your poſtpoy, and trive you to Chychwechlyn, and as you was never married, how telighted you'll be with noiſes, and viſits, and confuſions!

l.hi: Tol lol, de rol, lol,
My Tolly, my Toll,
With me when you canter to Wales,
For petticoat white,
Buff breeches ſo tight,
Away go needles and flails.
Young Taffy throws by hur wheels,
Then Winney kicks up her heels,
With follow
And halloo,
And waddle
And ſtraddle,
So merry to ſee us come;
With fiddle
And diddle,
In giggle
And wriggle,
They give us a welcome bone.
The joy ſo great,
So noble we treat,
An oxen is roaſted whole!
And tho' on the lawn
The ſpiggot is drawn
For punch, you may ſwim in the bowl!
We give the ladies a ball,
We foot it away in the ball.
With follow, &c.
Miſs Howell ſo nice,
And Lady ap Rice,
And couſin Sir Evan ap Floyd,
Parſon Montgomery,
Counſellor Flummery,
〈…〉 ap Williams, Ap Floyd.
〈◊〉 when the ſtocking is thrown,
〈…〉 I a • o • e;
Then follow, &c.

sp.speaker: Dolly
sp.p: So, one can't go without dancing pumps, and the other can't go without jack-boots. If any of my old ſweethearts were to come in now, I ſhould be inclined to give them both the double.

sp.speaker: Lack
sp.p: So, at laſt I've found her.—Madam, your moſt obedient. Well, it's ſettled. I'll marry you.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Marry me!

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Yes; but don't let your joy carry you away. I ſaid I would.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Said! to who?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: To myſelf. And if a gentleman breaks his word with himſelf, who do you think he'll keep it with?—You're very handſome, my dear, that you are; and I would not tell a lie for all the women in France.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Lord! what a high notion of honour he has! and he's a much handſomer man than either Sir Shenkin or the Colonel—But my father ſays, that you arn't worth any thing, that you've no eſtate.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: That's a good joke i'faith! No eſtate! He might as well have ſaid I borrowed a guinea of him.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: I'faith! and now I do think of it, he did ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Did he indeed? that's very diverting truly. Ay, and he might as well have ſaid I borrowed theſe cloaths.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: That's what I thought of your fine cloaths, that you muſt have a great eſtate.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Not an acre. And to be ſure I've no ſeat in Herefordſhire—no parks—no orchards—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Orchards in Herefordſhire! Then I dare ſay you make twenty Hogſheads of Cyder in a year.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Cyder—Oh! you accompliſhed—Garlick Hill—Yes; and he might as well have ſaid that I've no houſe in Portman Square. Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Portman Square! Oh dear!—then I ſhall live in Portman Square!

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Ay, and without a guinea in the funds, or half a crown in my pocket at this moment. Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Ha! ha! that's very true. Now then, will you anſwer me one queſtion? If you was to agree to run away with me, would you wait for jack boots or dancing pumps?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Jack boots and dancing pumps! Not for the button of king Lewis's hat. You are frank and free. I love you; and thus I throw myſelf and all my fortunes at your feet. Now if we had but a parſon and a chaiſe!—

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: There's one in the houſe, and t'other at the door.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Is there? Then my dear—Garlick Hill— come along.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: Now, madam, now I'm for you; now I'm piſtol'd and booted.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Come, Miſs a de Bull.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: Come, Miſs Pull, my tear.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Why, where is ſhe gone?

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: Where did you put her?

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Why, vat have you done vid her?

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: I did leave her here.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Vell, and I did find her here.

div.stage: Enter Sir John and Lady Bull.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Where's my child? where's Dolly Bull?

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Dat fellow in de boots can tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come, come, none of your Welch tricks upon me. Give me my daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: 'Tis that deviliſh Gaul has got her.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay, you would not give your daughter to a Briton, and now you ſee ſhe's ſnapped up by that Frenchman. But I'll Creſſy and Agincourt you! Why, with Doll's fortune, I could build a man of war, and batter your breaſt-work. I'll come like the ghoſt of Hawke, and beat you! I'll be a Black Prince to you!

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: You are much miſtaken now, as you vas ven you took me for a tailleur. I tell you that poſtillion in boots has ſtole her.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: No, no, I ſay 'twas you.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: I ſay 'twas you.

l.hi: 'Twas you, ſir, 'twas you, ſir;
I'll thraſh you black and blue, ſir;
'Twas you that ſtole my daughter Doll;
'Twas you, ſir, you.
'Tis true, ſir, 'tis true, ſir;
But this affront you'll rue, ſir;
'Twas you that ſtole my daughter Doll;
'Twas you, ſir, you.
Oh, Ma'am, no, ma'am, no, no, no, no, no, ma'am;
How can you wrong me ſo, ma'am?
I did not ſteal your daughter Doll;
But I know who.
No, ſir, no, ſir; no, no, no, no, no, ſir;
How can you wrong me ſo, ſir?
I did not ſteal your daughter Doll;
But I know who.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Diable! n'importe—Damme!

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: This is frantics and inſanities. But by the got of war, if I had you at home, you ſhould give me ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Satisfaction!—I can a fight, or I can a let it alone. "I can fight and can conquer again and again."

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: Got pleſs hur! I wiſh I had him at Tover, I'd teach him to conquer. You are now in your own houſe, and you may ſtay there. For my part, I've got on my boots, and I am reſolved—I am reſolved—to walk down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh! what a bloody reſolution!—ſtop the boots!

div.stage: Exeunt Sir John and Lady Bull.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: "I can fight, &c.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Lord! how I do wiſh to get back again to England!—A girl like me to be a chambermaid, and to a taylor!—Well, I'm convinced if I'd as good cloaths, I ſhould look as well as Roſa.

l.hi: When dreſt in all my fineſt things,
My gold repeater, bracelets, rings,
In toilet glaſs,
A lovely laſs
I view, ſo gaily glancing;
I can't tell how,
But ne'er till now
I felt my heart a dancing.
With a fal, lal, la,
And a ha, ha, ha!
You've ſet my heart a dancing.
The coach is come—down ſtairs we trip,
The Opera—Robin plies his whip,
What ſparkling eyes!
Sir Fopling cries!
As to our box advancing;
I don't know how,
Yet ne'er till now,
I felt my heart a dancing.
With a fal, lal, la, &c.
Sultana queen at maſquerade,
Or nun, or humble village maid,
So fine, ſo bright
The ſparkling night,
Like fairies nimbly prancing;
I don't know how,
Yet ne'er till now,
I felt my heart a dancing.
With a fal, lal, la, &c.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: I have de two impoſteurs ſafe, if I can keep them.—So, mam'ſelle Nannette, you tink ver little of me. Noting vill ſerve a you but de Engliſh officier. Juſt now I was taken for Colonel Epaulette. You ſay I ugly. Never you tell a man he's ugly in his own houſe.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Lord, ſir! I don't think you ugly.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Don't you? Den I vill give a you de ſilk gown.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: No, ſir, I never did think you ugly. I always, I always thought you very pretty.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Did a you?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I did indeed—as I hope for the ſilk gown.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: No, not prett—but very ſmart, comely—a very ſmart, comely, little fellow.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: No, ſir, very pretty.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Vel den, pretty—a very pretty, little, ſmart fellow. But know, I have von grand affaire, great buſineſs, as good as hundred guinea; ſuch diſcovery of my two lodger—

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Indeed, ſir!

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Ay, Nannette know nothing of de diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Miſs Roſa rings her bell.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Stay. Where are you going? You are in a deviliſh hurry to get to de fellow.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Fellow! who do you mean?

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: When the bell rung, why did you not ſend the girl to me?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Send a de girl? vat an impudent fellow!— Pray von you did take a my lodging, vas dat in de bargain?

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: Nannette, will you ſtep into my chamber?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: No, indeed, ſhe von't.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I was juſt coming, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe vas coming.—Get out of de room! Yes, ſhe vas juſt coming—Get out of de room from de fellow.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: I only want ſome powder.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: You ſhall get no powder or ball here. Fighting fellow!—I viſh he vas out of my houſe (aſide.) If you want ſuch cut-throat tings, vhy don't you go to your own Hyde Park? Dat's the beſt place for lord-ſhooting.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: How impertinent the fellow is! And lord Wi • love to forſake me at ſuch a time! For him I gave up all my peace of mind—But I'll aſk pardon of heaven and my brother, and return to the convent.

l.hi: How can man ſuch pleaſure find,
Still in trying each endeavour
Thus to win the virgin's favour,
Softly ſteal into her mind,
And deſtroy her peace for ever;
With her heart,
To depart,
I eaving only grief behind.
Thus the boy, a linnet caging,
How engaging!
Now her ſweet and warbling ſong,
Soon neglected,
All rejected;
Poor thing! ſhe may her ſong give o'er,
Her ſweeteſt notes can charm no more.

sp.stage: (Lapoche watches her off, then runs and locks the door.)
sp.p: Dere now I tink I have de bold capitaine ſafe. Now I have got lock up dis deſperate fellow I have got de hundred guinea under my own key; and de diable a penny ſhall monſieur Lackland get. But I muſt go for de archer.—Here comes de nun in boots.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Well, ſir; where is the lady?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: De lady not far off. I fancy ſhe may be found in boots.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: In boots!

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Yes. Don't a you feel yourſelf uncomfortable in boots?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: In boots!—Come, come, where is the lady?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: How finely I vas deceived to take you for a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, what have I done to forſeit that character?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: But pray a now, don't you find yourſelf uncomfortable without de petticoat?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! will you fetch me one?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: I dare ſay Nannette will accommodate you.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Very acommodating truly!—No, Mr. Frenchman; I have crimes enough already without adding the ruin of Nannette.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Ruin! She may give you von you know; von can't ruin her.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Very commode indeed!—Yes, ſiſter Roſa, you're got in a very pretty ſort of a houſe.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Pray—ha! ha!—pray—upon my vord, ſhe looks vaſtly well in her boots.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Go, ſir, do you banter?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Ay, and do you go to your chamber, child, and I vill ſend Nannette to you. Poor thing! I dare ſay ver fatigue.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh Roſa! She was my ſiſter. Lord Winlove was a friend; and but for thoſe uhappy misfortunes, for thoſe fatal circumſtances, my proſpects with Celia appeared ſo pleaſing—how bleſt might I have been!

l.hi: Let fame ſound the trumpet, and cry "to the war!"
Let glory re-echo the ſtrain;
The full tide of honour may flow from the ſcar,
And heroes may ſmile on their pain.
The treaſures of autumn let Bacchus diſplay,
And ſtagger about with his bowl;
On ſcience, let Sol beam the luſtre of day,
And wiſdom give light to the ſoul.
Let India unfold her rich gems to the view,
Each virtue, each joy to improve;
Oh, give me the friend that I know to be true,
And the fair that I tenderly love!
What's glory but pride? a vain bubble is fame,
And riot the pleaſure of wine;
What's riches but trouble? and title's a name,
But friendſhip and love are divine!

div.stage: Lapoche watches him off, then locks the door on him.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Vell ſaid, Roſa—Dere now I have got yo both ſafe; and I have de archer ready for dis capitaine.—Oh! here be de gentlemam that came after the lady firſt.

sp.speaker: Lord W.
sp.p: Now I ſhall ſee Roſa's new flame.— Well, my friend, where is the captain that run away with Roſa?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: What the nun in boots?

sp.speaker: Lord W.
sp.p: Nun in boots! I mean the officer that went off with the nun that you told me of.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: I have him ſafe; but he's the diable of a fellow, and has been aſking for powder; ſo have a de care.

sp.speaker: Lord W.
sp.p: Well, let's ſee this devil of a fellow.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Shall I call in de archer? I have him ready.

sp.speaker: Lord W.
sp.p: Pho! Let me ſee the the captain. Open the door.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Yes, but I'll have de reward (opens the door.) —Dere— (runs round to the other door.) Now I'll ſee if my nun in boots is ſafe.

sp.speaker: Lord W.
sp.p: My dear Roſa!

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: My dear lord!

sp.speaker: Celia .
sp.p: I only want to ſee the gentleman.

div.p: I beg pardon. I want to ſpeak with the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Well, here are three gentleman.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Yes; but I want to ſpeak with the Engliſh officer that lodges here—that is in cuſtody.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Oh! de nun in boots—more diſguiſe. I dare ſay this is ſome Engliſh conſtable come over to take up de capitaine for killing de lord.

sp.speaker: Henry .
sp.p: What do you mean by locking me in? Open the door, or I'll break it open

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Break open my door! for ſhame, is dat behaving like a nun?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Lord Winlove alive!

sp.speaker: Lord W.
sp.p: Yes, Henry. Are you ſorry to ſee me?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Indeed, my lord, I am doubly happy to find myſelf guiltleſs of your blood, and you alive to do my ſiſter that juſtice I'm ſure you intend.

sp.speaker: Lord W.
sp.p: Harry, my intentions were ever honourable; and that my immediate union with my Roſa ſhall evince. Your love for your ſiſter hurried you to a raſhneſs that was near proving fatal; but this cancels every error.

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: My Celia!

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Indeed I don't know how to apologize for this ſtrange intruſion. Captain, don't be vain if I ſay 'twas on your account.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Siſter Roſa, this happineſs is unexpected. And now give me leave to introduce you to a lady, who intends ſhortly to honour our family with her alliance.

sp.speaker: Lord Winlove, Henry, Celia, and Roſa.

l.hi: How ſweet, how kind the joyful hours,
With peace and virtue crown'd!
They come like ſoft deſcending ſhowers,
To cheer the landſcape round
Huſh, throbbing heart, as truth alone,
Should light the virgin's breaſt,
Retire, cold freezing doubt, begone,
Retire, 'tis love's requeſt!

div.stage: Enter Dolly, Lackland, Sir John and Lady Bull.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Make haſte or they'll catch us.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Let's rally and face them.

sp.speaker: Sir John .
sp.p: I know they are here. You're a pretty lady

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Softly, Bull; no abuſe.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why damme, mayn't I ſpeak to my own child?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Nobody, ſir, muſt abuſe my wife.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Wife! I ſhall run mad! My daughter married to a fellow without a ſhirt! a fellow that borrowed a guinea of me this morning!

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ay, you would have an Engliſh huſband! She may have married Barrington for aught you know.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I hope he's a rogue.

sp.speaker: Lord W.
sp.p: Wiſh your ſon a rogue!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: If he's myſelf I hope he's a rogue. I'll have no more mercy on him than the king of Pruſſia would have upon a Dutch alderman.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: So, Miſs Toll, I hear you have made matches and matrimonies.

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes; ſo now you may canter off to Cychwechlyn as faſt as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: Give you joy of your tom-tit; for ſhe was never good, egg or bird.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Oh Dolly, how could you take up with ſuch a perſon?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Why, the colonel could not go without dancing pumps, nor Sir Shenkin without jack-boots, ſo that I was very glad to take up with any body.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Very much obliged to you, madam.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: How do you all, good peoples? How does my lady Bull-dog! damme?—So, miſs, you're married?

sp.speaker: Dolly.
sp.p: Yes, and without waiting for dancing-pumps.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Bull-dog! If you are a Frenchman, behave like one.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: I never will behave myſelf, damme!

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Colonel Epaulette, let me entreat you to leave off attempting the blunt honeſty of the Engliſh. It only transforms your countrymen into brutes. The attempt is as ridiculous as for the rough Engliſh to ape the cuſtoms and manners of the French, where we ever miſs the mark, and poliſh into puppies.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin
sp.p: Well, you made the bets, when ſhall we ſhare?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: No! I paid forfeit. Joan did walk over the courſe.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: And did you ſuppoſe I could behave ſo contemptible to join in ſuch a ſcheme?

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p:
It's fery well; you ſhan't have my
ſiſter. Look you, I do deſire that you will never ſpeak to, look at, or think of Celia again.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Look you, Sir Shenkin, if you don't immediately pay me the five thouſand you laid me, and give your conſent to my marrying your ſiſter, I'll refer your conduct to the jockey club; and 'tis ſo notorious, that you'll not only be excluded the turf here, but at every race in England.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why, my little Welchman, I am afraid you'll be poſted at Tatterſall's.

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: I'm nick'd, ſous'd and ſlamm'd. Here, take my ſiſter Celia. I'll back him againſt the field; for he has tricked me that have nicked hundreds.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Sir Shenkin, this is the firſt good I ever knew derived from gaming. For what ſenſation muſt that man be capable of, that builds upon the miſery of others; and raiſes a fortune on the ruin and bankruptcy of his fellow-creatures!

sp.speaker: Sir Shenkin.
sp.p: It may be ſo; but as I ſet out a young pigeon, I'm reſolved to die an old rook.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But how ſhall I get this rook out of my pigeon-houſe?

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Vell, monſieur Lackland, I have procured you a commiſſion in my regiment; and 'tis much at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I thank you, Monſieur; but while I can raiſe the price of a drumſtick, I'll never pull a trigger or draw a ſword againſt my native country.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Bravo! my boy. Give me your hand. And at dinner time you ſhall never want a nail in my parlour to hang your hat on. You ſhall poſt my ledger, and drive a gig.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Gig! Why you ſhall ride in a vis-a-vis, to the amazement of all Garlick hill.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh rare! My dear and I tide ſide by ſide in a vis-a-vis!

sp.speaker: Sir Shenhin.
sp.p: And look you, for all your underminings and circumventings, if you whip your tomtit down to Chychwechlyn, I'll give you a haunch of rock veniſon, and a pottle to waſh it down.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Rock veniſon!—Oh! he'll give you the leg of a goat.—Well now; as we ſeem now to be all tolerable good friends, we'll retire to the inn— (Lady Bull locks) Hotel I mean, where Engliſh hoſpitality ſhall receive the zeſt of French claret.— Heigh! what ſay you to that, my antigallican ſonin-law?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: With all my heart. But, ſir, I'll have no illiberal prejudices in my family. National reflections are unworthy the breaſt of an Engliſhman; and however in war each may vindicate his country's honour. in peace let us not know a diſtance but the ſtreights of Dover.

l.hi: Let faſhion with her glittering train,
Abroad a while deceive us;
We long to ſee dear home again,
The love of England muſt remain,
And that can never leave us.

sp.speaker: Lord Winlove, Henry, Roſa, and Celia.

l.hi: This patrist fire within each heart,
For ever let us nouriſh,
Moy England over flouriſh!
My future range,
The ſtock-exchange,
'Tis there I'll mind my paces;
Nor gig, nor nag,
Jack Bull ſhall drag
To French or Engliſh races.
At feaſt or ball,
At Grocers-hall,
'Tis there I'll mind my paces;
Yet nothing keep
Me from a peep
At French or Engliſh races.
Our bard ſtill in your favour thrive,
His jokes your fancies tickling,
This boon in laugh and claps then give
To Shenkin of Cychwechlyn.
And now of each doubt and perplexity eas'd,
From Fontainbleau races we'll prance.
In hopes that all errors our friends will be pleas'd
To excuſe, as 'tis "Our Way in France."
A patriot fire within each heart
For ever let us nouriſh,
Of glory ſtill the golden mart,
May England ever flouriſh!

div.head: This Day is Publiſhed,
div.p: By order of the Lords Commiſſioners of the Admiralty, in three volumes large octavo, illuſtrated with a volume in quarto of Plates, neatly engraved, Price One Guinea in boards, or 1l. 6s. bound.

A NEW EDITION of AVOYAGE TO THE PACIFIC OCEAN. undertaken by order of His Majeſty, for making diſcoveries in the Northern Hemiſphere, with a view to determine the poſition and extent of the Weſt Side of North America, its diſtance from Aſia, and the practicability of a Northern Paſſage to Europe.
Performed under the direction of Captains COOK, CLERKE, and GORE, in his Majeſty's ſhips the Reſolution and Diſcovery, in the years 1776, 1777, 1778, 1779, and 1780.

Written by JAMES COOK, Commander of the Reſolution, and, from the time of his death, By JAMES KING, late Commander of the Diſcovery. The Maps and Charts are from original drawings, by Lieutenant H. Roberts, under the inſpection of Captain Cook.
DUBLIN, re-printed for W. WILSON, No. 6, Dame-ſtreet. the corner of Palace-ſtrees.
